title: Three Major Types of Git Objects
content: Commit: metadata (author, timestamp, message) → points to a tree
Tree: directory structure → points to blobs/trees
Blob: raw file data

title: Initial Structure
content: Imagine you cloned a repo with just hello.c. Under the hood:
• A commit marks the snapshot

title: Initial Structure
content: Imagine you cloned a repo with just hello.c. Under the hood:
• A commit marks the snapshot
• That commit points to a tree

title: Initial Structure
content: Imagine you cloned a repo with just hello.c. Under the hood:
• A commit marks the snapshot
• That commit points to a tree
• The tree points to a blob containing hello.c

title: Making a Commit
content: Now let's add a Makefile and commit it:
code:
echo "hello:" > Makefile
git add Makefile && git commit -m "Add Makefile"

title: Committing a Change to an Existing File
content: Edit hello.c, then commit again. Git:
• reuses the same blob for unchanged files
• creates a new blob if the file changed
code:
vim hello.c
git add hello.c && git commit -m "Add an epic line"

title: Subdirectories
content: Git represents folders via nested trees. Example:
code:
mkdir subdir
echo "abc" > subdir/notes.txt
git add subdir/notes.txt && git commit -m "Track notes.txt"

title: The Index
content: The .git/index is your staging area. It maps filenames → blob hashes before you commit.
It is a binary file that contains a list of files and their corresponding blob object hashes.
code:
vim hello.c
git add hello.c 
git commit -m "Add a line about the index"

title: Tutorial Complete!
content: You've seen how Git creates & links blobs, trees, commits, and uses the index.
